culturalStories.title: The Origin of Kente
culturalStories.content: Long ago, two friends from the village of Bonwire, Kurugu and Ameyaw, went hunting in the forest. While resting under a tree, they noticed a spider spinning a web with an intricate pattern. Fascinated by the beauty and complexity of the web, they returned to their village and tried to recreate the pattern using threads. Their creation became the first Kente cloth, and the knowledge was passed down through generations.

culturalStories.title: Kente and Royalty
culturalStories.content: Kente cloth was originally reserved exclusively for royalty in the Ashanti Kingdom. The gold threads represented the wealth and prestige of the kingdom, while the intricate patterns symbolized the king's wisdom and authority. Only the Asantehene (king) and his closest advisors were permitted to wear certain patterns. Today, Kente is worn by many people for special occasions, but specific designs still maintain their royal significance.

culturalStories.title: The Language of Colors
culturalStories.content: In Kente weaving, each color carries specific meaning and communicates different aspects of Akan philosophy. Gold symbolizes royalty and wealth, blue represents peace and harmony, green signifies growth and renewal, red symbolizes political and spiritual energy, black represents spiritual maturity, and white symbolizes purification and festive occasions. By combining these colors in specific patterns, Kente weavers create cloth that tells stories and conveys cultural values.

culturalStories.title: The Art of Kente Weaving
culturalStories.content: Traditional Kente is woven on a horizontal loom that uses a warp and weft technique. The weaver creates thin strips about 4 inches wide, which are later sewn together to form larger cloths. A full-size traditional Kente cloth might contain more than 20 strips. Master weavers train for years to perfect their technique, learning to create increasingly complex patterns that require precise coordination and mathematical understanding. The warp threads (vertical) provide structure, while the weft threads (horizontal) create the vibrant patterns.

aiHintTemplates.noBlocksHint: Start by adding a pattern block like Dame-Dame (checker) to create your first design.
aiHintTemplates.noPatternHint: Add a pattern block to define the structure of your design. Try the checker or zigzag pattern!
aiHintTemplates.noColorHint: Add color blocks to bring your pattern to life. Traditional Kente uses gold, black, red, and green.
aiHintTemplates.needConnectionHint: Connect your blocks by dragging from connection points between blocks.
aiHintTemplates.goodProgressHint: Great work! Try combining different patterns and colors to create more meaning.

aiHintTemplates.noLoopHint: Try adding loop blocks to create repeating patterns, like traditional Kente strips.
aiHintTemplates.noStructureHint: Add row or column blocks to organize your patterns like the warp and weft threads in Kente.
aiHintTemplates.needVarietyHint: Traditional Kente uses multiple patterns and colors. Try adding more variety to your design.
aiHintTemplates.goodProgressHint: Nice work! Your pattern shows good understanding of intermediate Kente design principles.

aiHintTemplates.complexityHint: Try creating more complex arrangements using nested structures and multiple pattern types.
aiHintTemplates.colorSymbolismHint: Use color combinations with cultural meaning. Remember that each color tells part of the story.
aiHintTemplates.patternVarietyHint: Master weavers combine multiple pattern types in a single cloth. Try using more variety.
aiHintTemplates.goodProgressHint: Excellent work! Your pattern shows strong understanding of advanced Kente techniques.

aiHintTemplates.complexNestingHint: Master weavers create complex nested patterns. Try using nested loops for more intricate designs.
aiHintTemplates.culturalAccuracyHint: Focus on cultural authenticity. Each element should have specific meaning in Akan tradition.
aiHintTemplates.colorHarmonyHint: Perfect color harmony is essential in master-level Kente. Ensure your colors have balanced symbolism.
aiHintTemplates.goodProgressHint: Outstanding! Your pattern demonstrates mastery of Kente weaving techniques and cultural understanding.
